bibl.title: Letter from E.J. Scannell to Henry Rose Carter, September 4, 1923

div1.p: Scannell informs Carter that he has taken a trip through the northern states of Brazil and reports that Bahia and Ceara seem to be the chief yellow fever centers.

div1.head: Letter from E.J. Scannell to Henry Rose Carter, September 4, 1923
div1.opener:
TELEPHONE, CENTRAL 150
RUA TENENTE POSSOLO, 39
CONSELHO SANITARIO INTERNACIONAL
COMMISSÃO ROCKEFELLER
RIO DE JANEIRO, BRASIL
Sept. 4, 1923.
CAIXA POSTAL NUMERO 49
TELEGRAMMAS, INTERCOM RIO
Dear Doctor Carter;
div1.p:
I received your letter and will look
up that disease you mentioned.
Am so sorry you are not in the
field also but already you have
more than done your bit it would
appear to me. Not many have such
a long and useful trail as yourself
to look back at - you have certainly
much to be proud of.

We are waiting just now for plans
to be matured before actually
beginning work. Dr. White and myself
are here at the Hotel Gloria right on
the beach and it is wonderful. We have
just returned from a trip through the
northern states, to Para and return.
TELEPHONE, CENTRAL 150
RUA TENENTE POSSOLO, 39
CONSELHO SANITARIO INTERNACIONAL
COMMISSÃO ROCKEFELLER
RIO DE JANEIRO, BRASIL
CAIXA POSTAL NUMERO 49
TELEGRAMMAS, INTERCOM RIO
Bahia and Cearà appear to be
the chief centers for yellow fever
just now. Hope to get to work
shortly.

What a wonderful country this
is- I had no idea it was or
is so vast and rich and also
has been scarcely touched as yet.
Please commend me to Miss Laura.
Shall write you later about
that disease, I shall not attempt
to name it.
I hope this finds you well.
div1.closer: Very respectfully yours, E. J. Scannell.
